text:
- Welcome to Billion Dollar Napkin, where we discover how some of
Australia's brightest startups prove that their creative, innovative,

impactful ideas were possible. (upbeat music) You'll hear about the
triumphs, the failures and the pivots, everything
from their early beginnings

through to how they got things made. Three drinks, please. (bottles clang) - I think our first
month of revenue was $80.

- That was the result of 13
or 12 months work as well. - Literally sitting there at
the dinner table on date night,

doing customer support chats with your girlfriend absolutely
death staring at you. - [Adam Voice-Over] In
this, the first episode

of "Billion Dollar Napkin,"
we'll chat to Alex and Angus from Brisbane-based
crypto platform, Swyftx.

Find out what it's like
to go from an $80 income to signing a $1.5 billion deal.

How important is culture in
an organization like Swyftx, and is Brisbane really
the new Silicon Valley?

All that and more in
"Billion Dollar Napkin."

- Alex, Angus, thanks for joining me on "Billion Dollar Napkin."
- Thank you very much, Adam. - Hey, Adam, thanks for having us, mate.

- Who's got napkin drawing
duties out the two of you? - That'd be yours truly, over here.
- Why is that, Alex? Are you the more artistic one of the two? - I think we're both actually

probably the least artistic
people on the planet. We do work in tech, but we
did go to Steiner schools, and we did lots of creativity there,

so this is where we'll make
our teachers very proud. - Let's put that creativity to the test. Show me the Swyftx Billion Dollar Napkin.

- All right, so I guess
with traditional banking, when you need to pay someone,

you have to use a bank as an intermediary. The big appeal about crypto
and specifically, Bitcoin,

is you can't actually transact
without that intermediary, so the network itself
secures the transactions,
which means two people can transact, and that's gonna be particularly important for developing nations

that they don't have these
centralized banking systems. - So where does Swyftx come
into people trading crypto?

- Yeah, well right now, here in Australia, if you wanna buy Bitcoin
and invest in the currency,

you sign up to Swyftx, you deposit your traditional
Australian dollars into the account and
then you can pick from

any of the 300 different
coins that we have on there. You can invest in them, and then we'll put them
into the wallet for you

that's built into the platform, or you can then take them and
put them in your own wallet. - You are the device that's
helping millions of people

around the world get on the crypto thing. - That's exactly right. - And Swyftx was not your
first journey into crypto,

was it, Angus, you toyed
with something else? - That's correct, yeah,
so I had gone to crypto about 2014, and at the time,

there was a couple projects flying around, and I was quite technical and
ended up getting a contract working freelance for this
cryptocurrency called Opal Coin,

and essentially they were looking
to build out a marketplace that was really tightly
integrated into their coin itself,
so you could jump on that. It was like the gum tree equivalent, jump on that and you could trade.

It could be books, or
you could download music that a freelance producer had developed,

that kind of stuff, and yeah. - Alex, well before Angus was
earning his business chops,

tell us about juice on the loose. - Juice on the loose, how did I know you were
gonna bring that up?

(Angus and Alex laughing)
- I've done my homework. Juice on the loose, tell me about it. - Yeah, yeah, look, my grandparents

were into business a lot, and yeah, they had nine to 10
stores back in the day, and so I guess it runs in
the family a little bit

in terms of being entrepreneurial. My other grandparents build
and sell Jabber aircraft,

so light sport aircraft up in Bundy. And I was about 10 and went and set up a fruit juice
stand under local markets,

and I think I used to make $80 of profit for 12 hours of grinding
away on the juicer,

and that was without paying
for Dad and his time, but yeah, that was where I got started.

And then I think the novelty for my father wore off
of the 4:00 AM mornings,

got a bit sick of that,
so when I got a bit older, pretty much stole his tractor
and started mowing lawns

for the neighbors and whatnot. He did charge me
maintenance fees for that, so yeah, couldn't get that
one pass him, unfortunately.

From there, started on the push bike, going around in the neighborhood
dropping leaflets off,

and I'll tell you what,
Dad wanted to charge me to use his printer for my leaflets.

- (laughs) So you've
understood the full-on cost of operating a business
right from the start, yeah?

- I'll tell you what, I
absolutely hated him for it, but it was a very valuable lesson. Yeah, taught us that
nothing in life is free

and that it's all about a hustle, so I used to go and print
my flyers at school, because it was free there, so
yeah, very important lessons.

- I love this here, so you have this natural
entrepreneurial bent. You've got the tech side, but you're also quite techy
yourself in some ways,

'cause am I right that you met
at a summer computing school at the University of
Sydney, is that right?

- Yeah, that's correct,
so it was a course, essentially brought together 100
or 150 year-11 students together and put us together for two weeks and there was all sorts of challenges,

building a website, getting
rumors to do rescue operations and all this kind of jazz, and
we happened to be roommates,
and so there we were, two, I guess, nerds, (laughs) and yeah, looking at each other
and going, "Well, hello." - So randomly selected to room together out of 150 people at a summer school?

- Yeah. - We've never actually clarified it, 'cause we do go to the same
school but in different states,

but they weren't really connected. - So they might have said, "Let's put the Steiner
school kids together." - Yeah, yeah, yeah, let them
be friends or something,
I dunno, I dunno, but it was by chance. I think to say that we're both techy

is probably very complimentary to me and maybe an insult to Angus,
but Angus is the super brains

when it comes to the
tech, and I'm pretty sure that I submitted a WordPress
website as my coding project
to get into the thing, so I dunno, I dunno how I got in, but I did.

- Even within that summer school, you're rooming together
doing all these projects, did the idea for Swyftx
bubble up as early as that,

or was there just a general, hey we should work together on
something vibe at that stage?

- I think at that stage it
was just purely friendship, had a lot of aligned
interests, as Alex mentioned.

We went to the same category
of school, all into the tech. It was very, yeah, just aligned,
but it wasn't until six years later that we started to understand the problem

in the crypto markets, and we're like, being tech guys, problems
means find a solution for it. - This computer school is
year 11, going into year 12,
but in terms of going into year 12, did both of you go into year 12? - That's another loaded question.

(everyone laughing)
I defer. - So yeah, I did grade 12, and
I did a couple years of uni.

I was doing mechatronics and robotics. It was a bit of, I guess, an interest, but I wasn't finding it
something that really grasped me

and held me there, so
I deferred for one year and deferred a second year, and apparently that becomes
then permanent after that,

so I didn't actually
finish uni on that side. - But am I right, Alex, that after the year-11
summer computing camp,

you didn't go back to year 12? - Look, I started year 12
for yeah, a couple of weeks and then just decided I had my IT business

running on the side. I was teaching myself to code. I was just getting out
there, getting it done. I had a few my mates working for me,

and I thought, look, I'm
never gonna go to uni. I'm never gonna work for anyone else. I think I might have had a
part-time job at Wooley's still
at the time, as a scanner man on Sundays. But yeah, so from there I basically...

and I started a TAFE course for business, so I finished up early
year 12, did a TAFE course,

read all the content,
but did none of the... what's it called, the exam?
- [Angus] The assessment? - Yeah, the exams and the assessments.

- Seems to be, I'm spotting a theme here. (everyone laughing) - Yeah, so I reapplied, 'cause
there was a returning year
for the camp down in Sydney, and I think you still technically were supposed to be at school,

but they didn't ask, and
so I managed to sneak in. But we actually sponsor it now, so we're sponsors of the CSS program-

- [Adam] Oh that's beautiful! You sponsor the computer
science camp where you guys met? - [Alex] Yes.
- [Angus] Yeah.

And in parallel we've
sponsored our own bootcamp, so bring in pre grads

and people looking to move
into the industry shortly and give them a two week
taster of life at Swyftx.
They get to go through challenges, work with our engineering staff and on all these kinds of exciting things.

- So where did the idea
for Swyftx come from? I can imagine a couple of guys of your age with your interests looking at crypto.

You've already had a look at that going, "There's something here.
This is interesting. "Not everyone's on board, "but that we're on board with this,"

but to choose to build an exchange, am I right in saying
that's a pretty brave play
in this space? You could have gone for something smaller that was still genuinely crypto. Where did the idea for, actually no,

let's build the platform that
facilitates everyone else? - Early 2017, I hit up Angus.

I saw the price of Bitcoin
going up and I thought, look, this all makes sense. Obviously, I've got a
bit of a tech background.

And so I spoke to Angus and started actually buying cryptocurrency with the support of him,
and he showed me the ropes,

which was really awesome. And then I complaining to him, I'm like, "Why is the price of Bitcoin,
every time I Google it online,

"way less than the price "that I'm paying for it in Australia? And that's when big-brain
Angus over here goes,

"Well let's just buy it overseas "and sell it in Australia
at a cheaper price." And I was like, "That doesn't
check out, that's free money,

"and one thing I've been
taught my whole life "is there's no such thing as free money." - The guy who used to pay for
the printer toner at home.

I'm onto something. It's
too good to be true! - Yeah, exactly, but it turns
out it is actually a thing,

it's called arbitrage, and
it's where there's a difference in price between two different markets. It happens in all different
markets, not unique to crypto,

but particularly, it was
very prevalent in crypto, because it was a very
young market back in 2017,

and so that was actually
where we made our seed capital for bootstrapping Swyftx.
- For people listening who don't know, bootstrapping is basically when you choose to fund something yourself

or from a small group of people you know, as opposed to asking investors, "Do you wanna take a part of
the action and fund us?" Yeah?

- Yep, you wanna talk
about the decision process of what to do with the money? - Yeah, so we've been going
out for three or four,

five months or something like that, and we were looking at it and we're like, "Geez, this is almost
a deposit for a house,

"I wonder if, okay..." And then we were like, "Well, hang on, "we've actually identified
a problem here," and we were like, "Okay,
house, sure, yeah."

Can we start a business and
can we solve the problem that we were facing and, I guess, be a bit more altruistic in
terms of offering that benefit

back to, well, Australians,
but also the wider market? And so we were like, "Let's do
it, let's quit our jobs and-"

- Let's get a bit techy here, what was the nature of the problem? What was the nature of
the solve that was needed

to allow thousands and
now millions of people to trade in these cryptocurrencies?

- So the fundamental problem is that cryptocurrencies
aren't centralized. That's why people love them,
but it's also a negative for them. So when you've got isolated markets, the pricing in one market will be different to another market,

and you need to equalize those. And typically that was
people more in the know and not your average investor
and those kind of people,

so the vast majority of
people weren't aware of that. And so, we then,

along the lines of trying
to solve the solution or find a solution to the problem, we're like, "Okay, can we
bring these markets together,

"bring it under a single
interface, i.e. like Swyftx is now,

"a brokerage where you can go
and access global liquidity "from the comfort of an Australian company
"or local sport and that kind of stuff?" And that's what we've achieved so far.

- That is one of the biggest problems for new people getting into crypto is that it is really technical
and can be quite confusing.

So we are Australia's top-rated exchange. We have over 600,000
customers on our platform now,

and we are very heavily
stacked in customer support, and we care a lot about our customers,

supporting them, educating them, and building a platform for
them that's simple and easy. - Brisbane is the home of Swyftx.

Is that slightly unusual
in the startup scene, the tech scene in Australia? And what's the advantage
of being in Brizzy?

- Haven't you heard, Brizzy's
the new Silicon Valley. - There you go, tell me more!
(Alex and Angus laughing) - No, look, Brizzy's been great.
I think aside from the fact that Covid was handled really well in Queensland,
or I guess that's debatable depending on which premier you ask. We had a lot of people wanting to move

in the shadow of Atlassian and Canva, who are obviously very prevalent
in Sydney and Melbourne,

it is really helpful for new startups to be able to attract
that talent and compete.

It's a really hard space,
so in Brisbane we found that that's really enabled us to, I guess,

shine with the likes of
Go1 and Octopus Deploy, two other really successful
tech companies up there.

- Angus, I see you are
wearing the Queensland, maroon state of origin t-shirt
there, the color at least.

What does being a Brisbane-based
startup mean to you? - I think it's about
sharing that understanding that you don't have to go
to Silicon Valley or Sydney.

There's several million
people in Brisbane, and there's some amazing,
smart people there. So being able to have a place
where they can put their thinking to work and designing solutions around it and building out a company from it.

- We managed to convince our CTO to move back from the UK to
the Goldie, so it's also handy. - [Angus] Yeah.
(Angus laughs)

(upbeat music) - [Adam Voice-Over]
"Billion Dollar Napkin" is brought to you by Amazon Web Services. For over 15 years, AWS has
helped more startups launch,

build and succeed than
any other cloud provider. If today's episode inspired
you, with AWS Activate,

you can access free tools and resources to help you get started. Get up to $100,000 in AWS
credits and start building
with easy-to-use templates that allow you to launch your business idea in minutes.

For more information, visit
aws.amazon.com/activate.

AWS, prove what's possible. - When did you realize we've
actually got something here,

What was the first form this
took that was a working version of something that you could call Swyftx?

- I've been asked that a few times, and my go-to response is when
we were able to transition from Nutri-Grain into our
three bedroom and five fruits.

That's how you know you've
got product market fits. - Can you remember, but is there a first trade you facilitate? Is there a first sale of Bitcoin
from someone or something

that means wow, we're going now? - Day one, opening the
doors, it was early 2019,

but it definitely was not, "Oh we've hit the mark here, it's great!" It was very much like
a, "Oh, that was it?"

(laughs) All the processes
worked. We'd code it all up. The person could log in. They could get their account verified.

They could go and make that trade, but it was like, oh, that
was a year of our life, and we've invested our
life savings into it.

- Well just rewinding
to what you said before, it was buy a house or quit our jobs and take our entire savings

and invest it into building a business, so a business that was gonna
take us three months to build, that ended up taking 12,
and when we launched it,

it was at the bottom of
the bear market, I guess. Bitcoin was very low. - 12 Months in the
crypto world is forever.

The currency during that time
did take a major downturn, and you also started to
see a degree of regulation

or serious financial
institutions starting to say, "We might do a BT."

Did the banks hate you guys or pay no attention to you at that stage, and what was that speed
to get to market like?

- I think the banks, specifically, didn't pay too much attention to us, but we weren't their most
preferred customer, I guess.

There's unfortunately
those negative connotations associated with it, and so- - That intensity of trying to
have the product ready to go,

you wanted it in three months
and ended up taking 12, must have been really
demanding on the both of you. - Yeah, (laughing) definitely.

Angus, obviously, we have
established is the tech guy, so he spent a lot of
that time just grinding,

absolutely grinding away on the keyboard. I spent a lot of the time
working on those partnerships

with banks, literally
getting on the phone, calling every European, there's so many more countries in Europe

than I thought possible.
(Adam laughing) Europeans are much more- - Now, if you'd finished
year 12, you might have known
how many countries there were in Europe. - Yeah, yeah, my language studies, whoops. But yeah, look, certainly on the phone

to all these different banks,
and they don't speak English and trying to establish partnerships

and looking at what other
global exchanges have done, so- - That's three years ago. You're in your early 20s then?
- I'm 28 now, so four years ago, yeah, 24. - So is there a bit of pushback
from anyone watching this going, "With respect, you're a couple of kids."

- Well, when you're on your phone, they've got no idea how old
you are, so you're all good. (everyone laughing) No, look honestly, I think
in the modern day and age,

people almost expect
tech founders to be young and young entrepreneurial,
ambitious people,

so it's almost like the
stereotype, I guess, that you have young founders
building companies these days,

and the industry is
incredibly supportive of that, not just in crypto but across tech, and that's evidence as well,
us trying to provide that same,
you know, we feel old I guess now. There's new founders coming outta Brisbane

that are 17 and 18, so- - So a 53 year old bald,
chubby guy like me goes in, and says, "I've got an idea
for a crypto platform."
- Oh mate, don't be hard on yourself. (everyone laughing) - So when you get to market, that's not long before the pandemic,

and we hear anecdotally that that's when crypto just takes off. There's a lot of people in
Australia and around the world

forced to be at home, some of whom have streams
of money coming in that they didn't have before. We hear that a lot of
people started speculating
the price went up. Was the pandemic when the rocket ship really took off for you guys?

- I think it was definitely
a component of it. I mean before it had even taken
off, we were sitting there.

We all had laptops, fortunately, and we were like, "How are we
gonna go through this period? "Are we gonna be able
to keep developing up

"and keep pushing forward,
make sure that we've got "the customer service
there at the forefront?" And fortunately, it ended
up being just as simple
as everyone heading home. We sent each person a multi monitor setup,

like a dock that they could
plug in, and away we were going, and it was kind of the same thing. We had to set up, was it
Tuesdays and Fridays, I think,

that we had an hour for getting together and having a social aspect. I think we were playing
games or board games

or something like that online,
keep that real culture going, and I think that's been
a fundamental driver

for our success as Swyftx as a company. - I've read some things
about the Swyftx culture,

and it is like literally
ball pit in the office that does sort of- - I was told I wasn't allowed that.
(everyone laughing) - You fought, you fought, you fought. - Mate, check the floor plan, that's actually a storage ring.
- And the nightclub bathroom holding, but there's that fun to work,

because you're working really hard, is a part of the culture
you're trying to encourage? - Yeah, exactly, it's a bit
corny but work hard, play hard.
It is really what we see it. You've gotta celebrate those wins, support each other going along the way throughout the challenges,

and when you get to that next stage, and you've passed the hurdle, it's celebrations all around
and everyone bang together.

- Alex, at the awards
night that you won an award where I learned about juice on the loose,

you said quote, about the period of time, "There's been lots of growth
in leadership for Angus and I."

How have you had to grow
from these two mates who met up at a computer school, to had a good idea that sort of worked,

to now running an organization that trades not in the
thousands or millions, but sometimes in the tens of millions,

hundreds of millions,
billions of dollars space? - Yeah, well look, I think to your...

tying off on your growth question earlier, we went through the, I'm
gonna say four stages

of a startup, scale up very
quickly in four years I think,

so a lot of businesses
and a lot of leaders, I think have time, like years,

to go through each of those
stages and grow their teams and grow themselves and learn,
but we just did that on fast forward. So, we went from an idea in January, 2018

to launching January,
2019 to having, I dunno,

a couple thousand
customers in January, 2020. And then by 2021, we had 50,000 customers,
and then by the beginning of 2022, we are at nearly or just over 600,000.

So, we've gone through
the ideation, market fit, startup, scale up, just all super rapidly,

so certainly from a a
leadership perspective, I think the hardest thing, also coming from a bootstrapped business,

is that you go from
literally sitting there at the dinner table on date night doing customer support
chats with your girlfriend,

absolutely death staring you, to needing to build the
thing that builds the thing

that builds the thing that
services the customer, so you have to really
have this huge mindset.

We've reorganized our org structure I think literally every six
months to allow for autonomy,

and we've been really focused on a bottom-up approach on leadership. It certainly works in a small
organization, you need it,

someone who's really, I
guess, steering the ship and making sure everyone's
doing the right stuff, but then, as you get
bigger, that is your job.

Your job is to build the
infrastructure and the people and empower the people and hire people that are better, smarter
and more capable than you.

We are the youngest people in
our entire leadership team. We are surrounded by old farts, like you,

(Adam laughing)
that have done it before and have come from Commonwealth
Bank or Deutche Bank XE,

so we've got some really
experienced people in our senior leadership team that we spend time with
every single day to grow

and learn from and that's
been how we do it, I think. - Sometimes they say don't
go into business with family

or really good friends because
of the strain it all plays. Has it been a benefit for you
guys to be such close friends

or has there been times
where the friendship has genuinely been strained? - I think we'd have to
be kidding ourselves

if we said there weren't a
rocky road along the way. But I think the key thing for
us is just being persistent,

understanding we're in
it for a common goal. We understand the problem. We're trying to strive
to deliver this product

to service the customers, to make their experience just wow, and throughout all of that,
you kind of see through,

oh, they're actually trying
to go for that common goal but speaking a different
language to get there.
Or, I think more times than I can count, we'll have a discussion, and it's like,

oh, it's so frustrating,
neither one's aligning it. And then you reflect on it afterwards, I think he was saying
the same thing as I was.

- Alex, give me an example on the journey where you've really been
challenged as a leader and perhaps thought I dunno
if I want to keep going.

- I don't think there's ever been a moment where I've felt like I
don't wanna keep going. I absolutely live and breathe
and have since I was 10,

the challenges and what I
love the most about what I do is waking up every day and
being like, "Come at me."

- What do you got?
- What am I gonna learn today? What problems am I gonna solve today? And that actually is
what drives me so hard.
And I think my mom is always saying, "I have no idea how you sleep at night."
And honestly, when I get stressed, I just go and have a nap.

It just makes me feel refreshed. You got a new focused view on
the world, and you go for it.

So yeah, certainly I think
that's the sort of attitude you have to have as a startup founder.

You know, I've had
unsuccessful businesses before, and I've learned from those,
and you just gotta get up

and go again, and we've
been incredibly successful. - Tell me a bit more about the dynamic of how you two interact as leaders.

One of you is a bit more on the tech side. One of you is a bit more on
the business entrepreneur side. How do the two of you work together?

- I think the one word is 'complimentary.' So, as you mentioned, Alex has a very strong
entrepreneurial background,

myself, a very strong
technical background, and for us it was always
about picking the problems that we were the ones to solve.
And so, making sure that if it was, I don't know, building out the...

Or who's gonna be hired
into a certain role, 100% Alex's foray, back off, let him let him make the
right decision on that front,

and you can flip that in
reverse for the technical stuff. How are we going to have
the sign up flow work?

Great, there it is. The page
is done for it, so yeah. - What's the single skill of
Angus that you look at most

and go, "Gee, I wish I could do that." - His super computer brain,
(laughs) just all of it.

But yeah, I mean Angus and I have a fortnightly,
one-on-one for an hour, and that's about as often as
we see each other these days.

We just have such
different responsibilities across the organization now,
with Angus such focused on tech

and myself focused on operational
parts of the business. - On the technical side,

what's the toughest it's got, Angus? - Particularly, it coincides
with the journey as well.

Being bootstrapped, we will always need to get that next revenue to
be able to pay our staff,

to make sure that we're paying bills, all that kind of stuff. And so, as part of that,
you don't have time.

Your time is what your
customers dictate to you or the market dictates to
you and that kind of stuff. So, from a technical
aspect, being able scale it

without ever having that
time to prepare for it has been the biggest challenge, going from literally zero,
building out a product
that can actually generate revenue, and then making sure that it can continue to support your customer base

through all of their training and things, 'cause you can't let them down. You're dealing with people's
finances, their investments.

That's something you just can't screw up. - On the topic of scale, does
working with someone like AWS

prove a benefit because
one of their real strengths is that speed to scale,
scaling in minutes, not days,

knowing that technology's there behind you when you're brave enough
to take the next leap, does that help?
- 100%

So, coming into Swyftx, I
hadn't worked with anything other than like FTP uploads
or something like that,

which is kind of, you don't
really hear about that anymore. And so, having to try and
design the infrastructure
that we were gonna base our platform on, it was really awesome to be able to use

these prepackaged tools that
you can just grab outta the box from AWS and just spin them up. For us, it culminated into
two different sectors,

so first off was the AWS
credit side of things. And so, that allowed us to be able to pay
for our infrastructure bills for, I think it covered us for 12 months or so of our entire cost there,

so we were able to focus on other aspects or other costs within the business, like paying wages or
software licenses that,

without having to worry about
the infrastructure bill. And the other side of that was
access to business support. So being able to have a
technical account manager

on call, literally, to be
able to ring up and go, "I've screwed something up,"

or, "Something's not working
as I was expecting it to," or, "We've got a challenge, "and we don't actually yet
know how to solve this."

- And I did a startup to
scale up program in Brizzy, and AWS were a big part of that, I'd say.

The thing that, on the
less technical side for me, was just the amazing
networks and introductions

that I've had throughout that program and the programs that AWS has supported has been certainly
instrumental, and even now,

our COCE now is someone that
I met through those programs, so it's had really positive
impact from that perspective.

- You were made an offer to sell a significant part
of the organization for, and I'll repeat the amount here, $150,000.

When did that come in the storyline and how close did either
of you go to saying, "I really think we should do this."
